description: 2d4 gp. few feel the call later in life. While some clerics are tightly bound to their churches’ activities on a daily basis, others have more freedom CLERIC to conduct their lives as they please, as long as they do so in accordance with their gods’ wishes. The handiwork of the gods is everywhere—in places of natural Clerics of a given religion are all supposed to get along, though beauty, in mighty crusades, in soaring temples, and in the hearts of schisms within a church are often more bitter than conflicts worshipers. Like people, gods run the gamut from benevolent to between religions. Clerics who share some basic ideals, such as malicious, reserved to intrusive, simple to inscrutable. The gods, goodness or lawfulness, may find common cause with each other however, work mostly through intermediaries—their clerics. Good and see themselves as part of an order or body that supersedes any clerics heal, protect, and avenge. Evil clerics pillage, destroy, and given religion. Clerics of opposed goals, however, are sworn ene- sabotage. A cleric uses the power of his god to make his god’s will mies. In civilized lands, open warfare between religions occurs only manifest. And if a cleric uses his god’s power to improve his own lot, during civil wars and similar social upheavals, but vicious that’s to be expected, too. politicking between opposed churches is common.
